node.title: 'Simply eating dinner felt like an intense workout': Reporter Charles Brice spent two weeks in hospital with COVID-19
node.alt: A man in a wheelchair looking at the camera.
node.description: ABC News Breakfast reporter Charles Brice tested positive to COVID-19 and spent two weeks in hospital recovering. Here's what he discoveredÂ along the way.
node.content:
["The sound of my phone ringing filled the room as I wiped my nose in preparation to answer the call.", "Looking at the number, a smirk of disbelief covered my face as I subconsciously predicted\u00a0the outcome of what I was going to be told.", "The previous weekend I had visited Melbourne for a few days, seeing friends, my News Breakfast colleagues and attending an appointment.", "Living in Adelaide with little COVID-19 in the community, I was surprised at how busy the Melbourne CBD and riverbank areas were, despite daily case numbers regularly being north of 1,000.", "Bars and restaurants were full, foot traffic at an endless peak hour; life was back to normal.", "It was great to see and to be surrounded by people once again while being as COVID-safe as possible.", "I returned a negative result before flying to South Australia as per government requirements and again after being tested once I arrived in Adelaide on the Monday night.", "
Symptoms were mild at first
", "Waking on the Wednesday morning, my sinuses felt blocked,\u00a0but no other symptoms presented.", "That morning I went to work and did a live cross to News Breakfast about state politics outside the front of Parliament House, a busy thoroughfare for people that work in the city.", "", "
Charles Brice during a live cross for ABC News Breakfast.(ABC News: Brant Cumming)
", "With just a runny nose as my only symptom, I reluctantly went for a test, believing that it would be negative just like the two before it.", "That phone call was SA Health confirming my subconscious thought \u2014 I was COVID positive.", "The next four hours consisted of back-to-back phone calls to SA Health, as well as to family and friends to let them know of my diagnosis.\u00a0", "I spent most of the time\u00a0trying to convince them that I was in fact telling the truth.", "Although I am a fit 31-year-old, having added complexities of a high-level spinal cord injury meant that I was to spend the next two weeks at the Royal Adelaide Hospital.", "My interaction with anyone during that time was anything but human-like.", "The nurses and doctors donned head-to-toe in PPE so that basic facial features were unrecognisable.", "It was my new normal.", "My symptoms were mild, which the medical team credited to being double vaccinated.", "But with already reduced lung capacity and lack of diaphragm, the first 48-hours was a nerve-racking time\u00a0and the unknown and isolation just magnified it.", "By day three, my illness had worsened and the realisation of how serious this virus was had sunk in, despite COVID-19 being a daily topic of conversation at work and life in general.", "A chesty cough, high fevers, shortness of breath, headaches and chest tightness persisted for days, as did the lack of sleep and sheer exhaustion.", "By the end of the worst days, simply eating dinner felt like an intense workout.", "Being confined to a small hospital room was also exhausting; it metaphorically got smaller and smaller as the days rolled into one another.", "
Time to reflect
", "It also gave me a lot of time to think and to realise there were many things to be grateful for while being in hospital.", "The technology that made vaccines possible played a huge part in keeping my symptoms low, as did the staff in the RAH's infectious disease ward.", "Streaming services and video calls filled my days.", "In somewhat odd timing, Triple J's Hack program published a collaboration on what's it's like to date living with a disability, which offered a distraction.", "The Bathurst 1000 and the first Test in Brisbane seemed to be on at the perfect time for me to enjoy.", "But that enjoyment paled in comparison to when I was given the all-clear to go home and when that first ray of sunshine hit my face.", "I was able to interact with other people without layers of PPE and could again see those features that make us, us.", "Being back in front of the camera was a relief and a step towards normality, and after reporting on COVID-19 for the last two years I have a new-found appreciation of the damages it can cause."]
